questions.question: I asked her …………………………… she could help me.
questions.description: Either if or whether can be used to introduce an indirect yes/no question.

questions.question: We waited ………………………………. he turned up.
questions.description: Until shows time up to shows distance.

questions.question: ………………………….. I had invited a lot of people, no one turned up.
questions.description: We use though to connect two contrasting ideas. As shows the reason.

questions.question: I was delighted to hear …………………………… he was safe.
How would people live ……………………………… there was no electricity?
I invited them ……………………………….. they didn’t come.
questions.description: We use but to connect two clauses of equal rank expressing contrasting ideas.

questions.question: You are not better ……………………………. he is.
……………………………. she has a good job, she does not have to depend on her parents.
questions.description: Now that is similar to as.

questions.question: You should mend your ways ………………………….. you want to get into trouble.
questions.description: Unless means if...not. We can also write: You should mend your ways if you do not want to get into trouble.

questions.question: It was ………………………….. a pleasant morning that I went for a walk.
questions.description: Use such before adjective + noun use so before an adjective.
